questions.text: A 44 year old lady has numbness in the right little finger and aspect of the palm shown in the picture. The small muscles of the hand are weak. Which nerve is affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of numbness in the right little finger and loss of sensation of the palmar aspect on the marged region along with weakness of small muscles of the hand suggests a diagnosis of ulnar nerve palsy.

  • Ulnar nerve injuries typically occur near the wrist or elbow.
  • Low lesions (distal to the elbow), often due to lacerations or compression, lead to numbness over the ulnar one and a half fingers, wasting of intrinsic hand muscles, claw hand deformity, and a positive Froment's sign due to adductor pollicis weakness. Entrapment at Guyon's canal (pisohamate tunnel) is also a recognized cause, commonly seen in cyclists.
  • High lesions (proximal, around the elbow) result from fractures or dislocations. They cause paralysis of the ulnar part of flexor digitorum profundus, so the clawing is less pronounced and this phenomenon is called the "ulnar paradox." Sensory and motor deficits are otherwise similar to low lesions.
  • Treatment includes nerve repair, transposition, tendon transfers, and, in severe cases, distal nerve transfer using the anterior interosseous nerve.

Explanations of other options:

Median nerve (Option A): Injury to the median nerve near the wrist leads to impaired thumb abduction and sensory loss over the radial three and a half fingers, often with thenar wasting in chronic cases. When the lesion is higher up in the forearm, as with fractures or dislocations, additional paralysis of wrist flexors, forearm pronators, and the long flexors to the thumb, index, and middle fingers occurs, producing signs such as the pointing index and an abnormal pinch using extended distal joints.

Radial nerve (Option B): Radial nerve damage can occur at the elbow, upper arm, or axilla, presenting differently depending on the lesion level. Low lesions, often due to elbow trauma or surgical injury, result in inability to extend the metacarpophalangeal joints and weakness of thumb extension, while wrist extension remains intact, causing the wrist to deviate radially. High lesions, such as from humeral fractures, cause wrist drop due to paralysis of radial extensors and inability to extend fingers and thumb, with sensory loss limited to the anatomical snuffbox. Very high lesions, such as those from axillary compression (e.g., "Saturday night palsy" or "crutch palsy"), involve wrist and hand weakness along with paralysis of the triceps and loss of the triceps reflex.

Anterior interosseous nerve (Option C): Anterior interosseous nerve injury presents with pure motor weakness, classically causing inability to make the 'OK sign' due to flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus weakness, without any sensory loss.

questions.text: A 37-year-old retropositive patient is assessed for new onset right arm weakness. An MRI head shows a temporoparietal ring enhancing lesion. Which is the most likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of new onset focal neurological deficit and MRI imaging showing ring enhancing lesion in a retropositive patient suggests a diagnosis of toxoplasmosis.

  • Toxoplasmosis is a frequent and serious opportunistic infection in patients with advanced HIV, especially when CD4+ T-cell counts fall below 100-200/μL.
  • It typically arises from reactivation of latent Toxoplasma gondii infection, particularly in seropositive individuals.
  • Neurologic manifestations, including seizures, headaches, confusion, and focal deficits such as hemiparesis and aphasia are common.
  • MRI typically shows ring-enhancing lesions with edema as shown below and a definitive diagnosis may require brain biopsy, especially in seronegative patients.
  • Focal brain lesions in AIDS must be differentiated from CNS lymphoma, cryptococcosis, or PML.
  • Common imaging locations include basal ganglia, brainstem, and the cortico-medullary junction.
  • CSF findings may be minimal, with only slight elevation in cells and protein. Systemic dissemination can also affect lungs, heart, GI tract, liver, pancreas, and skin.
  • Toxoplasma pneumonia can mimic Pneumocystis, and cardiac involvement may lead to tamponade or failure.
  • Treatment consists of sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin for 4-6 weeks.
  • Immunosuppressed individuals, including AIDS patients and those treated with anti-TNF agents, are at greatest risk.

Explanations of other options:

HIV-associated dementia(Option A): It is a "subcortical dementia," characterized by deficits in executive function and short-term memory. Brain imaging, especially MRI and CT, commonly reveals cerebral atrophy. MRI may also demonstrate small T2 hyperintense lesions and scattered areas of increased density.

Behcet disease (Option C): Behçet syndrome typically presents with recurrent oral and genital ulcers, skin lesions, and uveitis, often affecting mucocutaneous tissues first. Other manifestations include arthritis and ocular involvement in the form of uveitis and hypopyon. CNS involvement is rare and includes brainstem or spinal cord lesions or cerebral venous sinus thrombosis.

Cytomegalovirus (Option D): In immunocompromised individuals, cytomegalovirus can cause systemic illness with constitutional symptoms and hematologic abnormalities, and in the CNS, it may lead to progressive dementia-like illness or ventriculoencephalitis with cranial nerve involvement.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of diplopia. On examination, she has double vision on looking to the left only. There is failure of adduction in the right eye, and nystagmus in the left eye whilst looking to the left. Which one of the following is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The control of horizontal eye movements is mediated by the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF), which sends direct input to the sixth cranial nerve nucleus on the same side and, through the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), connects to the third cranial nerve nucleus on the opposite side. This neural circuitry enables both eyes to move in unison toward the same direction.
  • Damage to the PPRF disrupts this coordination, resulting in an ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy where the eyes cannot turn toward the side of the lesion.
  • Internuclear ophthalmoplegia occurs due to damage to the MLF, which disrupts coordination between the eyes during horizontal gaze. In a typical unilateral INO, the eye on the affected side fails to adduct, while the eye on the opposite side exhibits abduction nystagmus as shown in the image below. Eye alignment is generally normal in the primary position, and convergence is usually maintained unless the lesion extends posteriorly or is particularly large.

Explanations of other options:

Superior rectus palsy (Option A): Weakness of superior rectus leads to defective upgaze and is commonly seen in third nerve palsy.

Inferior rectus palsy (Option B): Weakness of inferior rectus leads to restricted downgaze and can be seen in third nerve palsy.

Lateral rectus palsy (Option C): Lateral rectus is supplied by the sixth cranial nerve and weakness results in diplopia on looking to the affected side and face-turn to the same side.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man has presented the casualty with a right wrist drop. On examination he has an absent triceps jerk on the right as well as an area of sensory loss over the anatomical snuff box on the right hand. Which of the following nerves is affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features of wrist drop, absent triceps jerk, and sensory loss over the dorsum of the middle finger suggests radial nerve palsy.

  • Radial nerve injury can occur at different anatomical levels: axilla, upper arm, or elbow, and the clinical features vary depending on the site.
  • Low lesions, typically from elbow trauma or surgical procedures, affect finger and thumb extension but spare wrist extension due to preservation of proximal branches
  • High lesions, often from humeral fractures or prolonged compression, cause wrist drop with impaired thumb elevation and loss of finger extension, with sensory loss over the anatomical snuffbox.
  • Very high lesions, commonly from axillary compression like "Saturday night palsy" or "crutch palsy", result in complete paralysis of wrist, finger, and triceps muscles, along with absent triceps reflex.
  • Open injuries warrant immediate surgical repair or grafting, while closed injuries are often neuropraxias with potential for spontaneous recovery.

The following image shows a wrist drop.

Explanation of other options:

Median nerve (Option A): Injury to the median nerve near the wrist leads to loss of thumb abduction and sensory deficit over the lateral three and a half fingers, often accompanied by wasting of the thenar muscles. When the lesion is higher, such as in the forearm or elbow, additional paralysis of the forearm pronators, wrist flexors, and long flexors of the thumb, index, and middle fingers occurs. This results in the "pointing index sign" due to unopposed flexion of the ulnar fingers and a defective pinch grip where the patient uses the distal phalanges rather than the tips of the thumb and index finger.

Axillary nerve (Option C): Injury to the axillary nerve results in weakness of shoulder abduction beyond 15 degrees, due to deltoid muscle involvement, and leads to visible wasting of the deltoid. A small patch of sensory loss may be found over the lateral shoulder (the "sergeant's patch").

Ulnar nerve (Option D): Ulnar nerve palsy typically results in sensory loss over the ulnar one and a half fingers and weakness of the intrinsic hand muscles, leading to a claw-hand deformity more pronounced in low lesions. Muscle wasting of the hypothenar and interosseous regions is often visible, and tests like Froment's sign reveal compensatory thumb flexion due to weakened adductor muscles. In high lesions near the elbow, clawing is less apparent because the flexor digitorum profundus to the ulnar fingers is also affected, a phenomenon termed the "ulnar paradox."
