questions.text: A 24 year old tennis player finds that he is unable to extend his right wrist. On examination, there is weakness of the extensors of the wrist and digits. Which of the following structures are damaged?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The radial nerve may be damaged anywhere in its course. It is most commonly affected in the upper arm where it winds round the humerus and in the extensor muscle compartment of the forearm affecting the posterior interosseous branch.
  • Radial nerve palsy causes weakness of the wrist and elbow extension, and weakness of forearm supination. Sensory loss on the dorsum of hand and forearm may also be present.

Radial Nerve Palsy

questions.text: A 66-year-old man was admitted in the medicine department for evaluation of fever. He was on two different diuretic drugs on admission which were discontinued due to chronic hyponatremia. On day 1, he had a sodium of 112 mEq/L and on day 3 he had a sodium of 145 mEq/L after sodium correction. He had developed spastic quadriparesis and pseudobulbar palsy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome (ODS), formerly termed central pontine myelinolysis, often presents dramatically with symptoms such as quadriplegia and pseudobulbar palsy.
  • It is most frequently triggered by rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia or in hyperosmolar states, particularly in individuals with severe underlying illness or nutritional deficiency.
  • It arises due to the brain's delayed ability to reaccumulate osmolytes after rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia, leading to cellular stress, particularly in oligodendrocytes, and resulting in demyelination.
  • The central pons is most frequently involved due to its neuroanatomic susceptibility, and symptoms such as paralysis, speech and swallowing difficulties, diplopia, and altered consciousness may emerge one to several days after correction.
  • In severe cases, patients may develop a "locked-in" state. Extrapontine areas may also be affected, including the cerebellum, thalamus, basal ganglia, and cortex, with presentations such as mutism, ataxia, dystonia, catatonia, or parkinsonism.
  • Even slow correction of sodium can trigger ODS in vulnerable individuals, especially those with risk factors like alcohol use, liver transplantation, malnutrition, or low potassium.
  • MRI is crucial for diagnosis and is as shown below.
  • To prevent ODS, sodium correction should be limited to ≤8 mmol/L in 24 hours and ≤15 mmol/L in 48 hours.

Explanation of other options:

Multiple sclerosis (Option A): Multiple sclerosis can manifest with diverse symptoms based on where lesions occur, such as abnormal sensations (paresthesias), vision problems from optic neuritis or double vision, weakness in the limbs or face, and increased muscle tone (spasticity). Other possible signs include pain, coordination issues, dizziness, and occasionally bladder control or cognitive impairments. These symptoms may appear episodically or gradually worsen, and MRI typically shows demyelinating lesions, often in a pattern known as Dawson's fingers.

Tuberculous meningitis (Option B): Tuberculous meningitis results from the bloodstream dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It usually presents gradually with ongoing symptoms such as headache, fever, fatigue, night sweats, and neck stiffness. Cerebrospinal fluid findings often show increased opening pressure, a lymphocyte-predominant pleocytosis, elevated protein, reduced glucose levels, and raised adenosine deaminase.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Option C): Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is characterized by both upper and lower motor neuron involvement, leading to progressive muscle weakness, wasting, twitching, increased muscle tone, and exaggerated reflexes, usually affecting both sides of the body symmetrically. When the bulbar region is affected, patients may develop speech difficulties and emotional lability. Despite disease progression, sensory perception, eye movements, and control over bowel and bladder functions generally remain unaffected.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man who had been diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis ten years back presents with intense pain in the right hand. Over a course of 3 weeks, he noticed pain, numbness, and tingling of the skin over the fourth and fifth fingers of the right hand. On examination, he has weakness in the abductors and adductors of the fingers, and his hand is held in a clawed position. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features such as sensory loss over fourth and fifth fingers, claw hand, and small muscle weakness points to ulnar nerve lesion.

  • Ulnar nerve palsy presents differently based on the level of the lesion.
  • In low lesions, often caused by wrist trauma or lacerations, patients show claw-hand deformity with sensory loss in the ulnar one and a half fingers, weakness of intrinsic hand muscles, hypothenar and interosseous wasting, and a positive Froment's sign.
  • High lesions, such as from elbow injuries, affect the flexor digitorum profundus as well, reducing the clawing appearance (high ulnar paradox), though sensory and motor deficits remain similar.
  • Compression syndromes like Guyon's canal entrapment and cubital tunnel neuropathy may also cause similar symptoms.

The following image shows claw hand.

Explanation of other options:

Common peroneal nerve lesion (Option A): Injury to the common peroneal nerve, particularly near the fibular neck, leads to foot drop with inability to dorsiflex or evert the foot and a compensatory high-stepping gait. Sensory deficits involve the anterolateral leg and dorsum of the foot, and pain can be prominent.

Radial nerve lesion (Option B): Presenting features include loss of triceps reflex, wrist drop, and finger drop depending on the site of lesion.

Median nerve lesion (Option C): Associated with sensory loss over radial three and a half fingers, thenar wasting, and paralysis of wrist flexors.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with muscle weakness and difficulty swallowing. On examination, he has proximal and distal upper and lower limb weakness. There is wasting of the intrinsic muscles of the fingers and of his thigh muscles. Creatine kinase is mildly elevated and EMG findings are consistent with a myopathic process. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features of proximal and distal muscle weakness with mildly elevated creatine kinase and EMG indicating a myopathy suggests a diagnosis of inclusion body myositis.

  • Inclusion body myositis typically affects individuals over 50 years old, with a male predominance, and presents with gradually progressive muscle weakness and wasting.
  • The disease characteristically involves the finger and wrist flexors in the upper limbs and the quadriceps in the lower limbs, with asymmetrical weakness and common complaints of dysphagia.
  • Diagnosis is supported by mildly elevated or normal creatine kinase levels, and the presence of anti-cN1A (anti-cytosolic 5′-nucleotidase 1A) antibodies in a significant portion of patients.
  • Electromyography shows chronic myopathic features, and muscle MRI often reveals selective involvement of specific muscles like the flexor digitorum profundus and vastus medialis/lateralis, sparing rectus femoris.
  • Muscle biopsy reveals endomysial inflammation with CD8+ T cells and macrophages attacking non-necrotic fibers, along with rimmed vacuoles and beta-amyloid-like inclusions, most effectively visualized using p62 immunostaining.
  • Additional findings may include mitochondrial abnormalities like ragged-red and COX-negative fibers.
  • The disease progresses slowly, with most individuals needing a wheelchair within 10 - 15 years of symptom onset, and has limited response to immunotherapy.

The following image shows rimmed vacuoles seen in inclusion body myositis.

Explanation of other options:

Polymyositis (Option A): Polymyositis is a group of conditions that primarily causes symmetric weakness of the proximal muscles, progressing over weeks to months. It may be accompanied by cardiac, pulmonary, or joint involvement.

Dermatomyositis (Option B): Dermatomyositis is characterized by symmetric proximal muscle weakness along with distinctive skin findings such as a heliotrope rash on the eyelids, Gottron's sign and papules over joints, V-sign, and shawl sign. Patients may also experience joint pains, swallowing difficulties, and lung complications such as ILD, often linked to antisynthetase antibodies. Adult-onset cases carry a higher malignancy risk, especially within the first few years.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis(Option D): Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) presents with a combination of upper and lower motor neuron signs such as muscle weakness, atrophy, fasciculations, spasticity, and hyperreflexia, which progress in a symmetric distribution over time. Bulbar involvement can cause dysarthria and pseudobulbar affect, while sensory, bowel, bladder, and ocular functions typically remain intact even in advanced stages.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man has a 4 week history of sudden onset dizziness, and vomiting. He feels that the world is spinning and his balance is poor but his hearing is normal. On examination, he has no cerebellar signs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical history of sudden-onset dizziness and vomiting persisting for 4 weeks makes the diagnosis of vestibular neuritis most likely.

  • Vestibular neuritis is characterized by sudden-onset, constant vertigo accompanied by nausea and vomiting. It arises due to unilateral dysfunction of the vestibular nerve or labyrinth.
  • Unlike benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), symptoms persist even when the head is still.
  • Spontaneous nystagmus and results of the head impulse test help distinguish between peripheral and central causes. A normal head impulse test makes a peripheral lesion unlikely.
  • In older individuals with vascular risk, stroke must be ruled out even in the absence of overt signs.
  • Most cases of vestibular neuritis resolve on their own, although some patients may experience lingering dizziness and imbalance.
  • Glucocorticoids have uncertain benefit, antivirals are generally not used unless herpes zoster is suspected, and vestibular suppressants should only be used short-term.

Explanation of other options:

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (Option A): Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is marked by brief episodes of vertigo lasting less than a minute, typically triggered by changes in head position such as lying down, looking upward, or rolling in bed.

Friedreich's ataxia (Option B): Friedreich's ataxia typically begins before the age of 25 with progressive gait instability, frequent falls, and titubation, affecting the legs more than the arms. Neurologically, it presents with nystagmus, dysarthria, absent deep tendon reflexes, and loss of proprioception.

Acoustic neuroma (Option C): Vestibular schwannomas, also known as acoustic neuromas, typically present with slowly progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and reduced vestibular function. Vertigo is usually absent because central compensation occurs gradually.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is admitted with acute right sided weakness and slurred speech. He does not have a history of hypertension, diabetes or high cholesterol. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He complains of headaches and generalised limb weakness infrequently. On examination, he has hypotonia and weakness in the proximal muscles more than the distal muscles. His laboratory tests show a high lactate to pyruvate ratio. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on features of stroke in a young man and elevated lactate is MELAS

  • MELAS (Mitochondrial Myopathy, Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like Episodes) is the most frequent mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, commonly presenting before the age of 20.
  • Seizures are a frequent early manifestation, and patients often develop stroke-like episodes not confined to vascular territories, causing hemiparesis, cortical blindness, and hemianopia.
  • Associated features include hearing loss, diabetes mellitus, endocrine abnormalities like hypothyroidism and growth hormone deficiency, and elevated serum lactic acid levels.
  • Muscle biopsy typically reveals ragged red fibers, and neuroimaging may show stroke-mimicking lesions predominantly in the occipital and parietal lobes, along with basal ganglia calcification.
  • CSF protein is usually mildly raised, and angiography typically fails to show major vessel pathology.
  • Though there is no curative therapy, supportive treatment targets seizures, endocrine dysfunction, and stroke-like episodes.

Explanation of other options:

Polymyositis (Option A): Polymyositis typically presents with symmetrical, proximal muscle weakness that progresses over weeks to months.

Inclusion body myositis (Option B): Inclusion body myositis (IBM) typically affects individuals over 50 years old, with a slight male predominance, and presents as gradually worsening muscle weakness and atrophy. It characteristically involves the wrist and finger flexors in the arms and quadriceps in the legs, often asymmetrically.

Polymorphonuclear leukoencephalopathy (Option D): Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) presents with a range of neurologic symptoms such as visual deficits, weakness, ataxia, cognitive changes, and seizures, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, and is associated with JC virus infection causing multifocal demyelination in the brain.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with a 6 month history of depression and painful sensory disturbance in both legs. There are myoclonic jerks observed in his legs. His MRI scan reveals basal ganglia hyperintensity and EEG reveals periodic sharp wave complexes.. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features, imaging and EEG findings is Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

  • CJD belongs to the group of prion diseases and results from the accumulation of an abnormal isoform of prion protein (PrPSc), which is derived from the normal cellular form (PrPC) through a conformational change from α-helix to β-sheet structure.
  • This aberrant PrPSc is resistant to proteolysis and accumulates in neural tissues, causing neurodegeneration.
  • There are different forms of CJD: sporadic (most common), genetic, iatrogenic, and variant (linked to bovine spongiform encephalopathy).
  • Clinically, patients exhibit rapidly progressive cognitive decline, psychiatric symptoms (depression, anxiety, psychosis), and neurologic features such as myoclonus, visual disturbances, cerebellar ataxia, and pyramidal/extrapyramidal signs.
  • As the disease progresses, akinetic mutism and death typically occur within a year.
  • MRI imaging can show characteristic cortical ribboning and basal ganglia hyperintensities in about 90% of cases.

The following MRI image shows the characteristic cortical ribboning.

  • EEG may reveal periodic sharp wave complexes in later stages.
  • There is currently no effective cure and treatment is supportive. Imaging and EEG help in diagnosis, and detection of 14-3-3 protein in CSF is supportive but nonspecific.

Explanation of other options:

Huntington's disease (Option B): Huntington's disease typically presents between ages 25 to 45 with involuntary choreiform movements, behavioral changes, oculomotor disturbances, and progressive cognitive decline leading to dementia. Over time, chorea may give way to rigidity, dystonia, bradykinesia, and myoclonus, and many patients also exhibit psychiatric symptoms like depression, aggression, and psychosis.

Wilson's disease (Option C): Wilson's disease results from copper accumulation in various organs, presenting most often before age 30. Liver-related signs include jaundice and hepatomegaly, while neurological issues like tremors, speech problems, and gait disturbances are common. Psychiatric symptoms such as mood swings and irritability, the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings in the eyes, renal tubular issues, bone deformities, and hemolytic anemia are also seen in affected individuals.

Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (Option D): Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is a demyelinating brain disorder seen mainly in immunosuppressed individuals, caused by JC virus infection, and is characterized by diverse neurologic symptoms including vision loss, limb weakness, coordination difficulties, cognitive impairment, and seizures.

questions.text: A 39-year-old chronic alcoholic is admitted to ER with altered mental status, unsteadiness and inattentiveness. Which is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis based on the clinical features of altered mental status, ataxia, and inattentiveness is Wernicke disease for which IV thiamine should be given.

  • Wernicke’s disease is a potentially preventable neurologic disorder that arises due to a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1), most commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcoholism but also occurring in those with malnutrition, hyperemesis, cancer, dialysis, HIV/AIDS, or after gastric surgery.
  • The classic triad includes ophthalmoplegia, gait ataxia, and confusion, although most patients present with altered mental status, disorientation, and inattentiveness rather than all three features.
  • Ocular motor signs include horizontal nystagmus, bilateral lateral rectus palsy, gaze palsies, and occasionally ptosis. Gait disturbances are attributed to a combination of cerebellar and vestibular dysfunction along with polyneuropathy.
  • Pupils are generally unaffected but may become small with disease progression. Other associated signs may include tachycardia, orthostatic hypotension, and peripheral neuropathy.
  • Improvement in eye movement abnormalities may occur within hours of thiamine administration, but ataxia and gait issues resolve more slowly. About half of the patients are left with a residual wide-based, shuffling gait and poor tandem walking ability.
  • Over time, memory impairment and learning difficulties may become prominent, indicating the transition to Korsakoff's psychosis, characterized by amnesia, confabulation, and poor memory sequencing.
  • Pathologically, the disease features petechial hemorrhages and neuronal loss around the third and fourth ventricles and mammillary bodie Thiamine deficiency impairs cerebral energy metabolism by disrupting enzymes such as pyruvate dehydrogenase and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, leading to mitochondrial dysfunction and glutamate-mediated excitotoxicity.
  • Wernicke's encephalopathy is a medical emergency requiring prompt intravenous thiamine administration (500 mg IV TID for 2-3 days), followed by IM or IV thiamine for several more days, and subsequently oral therapy with B-vitamin supplementation.
  • Importantly, glucose should never be administered before thiamine in at-risk individuals, as it can precipitate or worsen the condition due to increased metabolic demand in a thiamine-deficient brain. (Option A ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

Lorazepam (Option B): In the setting of chronic alcohol use, lorazepam is used in conditions such as delirium tremens.

IV vitamin B12 (Option D): Since vitamin B12 has no role in the pathogenesis of Wernicke disease this option can be ruled out.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man has severe episodes of dizziness with associated vomiting and pain in the right ear which occurs once or twice a week. During these attacks he feels as if the surrounding environment is spinning around. He also mentions being able to hear a high pitched sound frequently which seems to originate from this ear. On examination, during an attack, he has right horizontal nystagmus. Audiological testing reveals right-sided sensorineural deafness. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical features of episodic vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss, and nystagmus is Meniere’s disease.

  • Meniere's disease is characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss (especially at low frequencies), aural fullness, and ear discomfort or pressure.
  • Audiometry during an episode reveals asymmetric low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, which may temporarily improve between episodes, although permanent loss can occur over time.
  • The condition is thought to arise from excess endolymphatic fluid in the inner ear, termed endolymphatic hydrops, although its precise mechanism remains unclear.
  • Initial treatment includes dietary sodium restriction and diuretics. If symptoms persist, intratympanic injections of steroids or gentamicin may be used.
  • Surgical options, if needed, include decompression or shunting of the endolymphatic sac, while ablative procedures like vestibular nerve section or labyrinthectomy are rarely necessary.

Explanation of other options:

Vestibular neuritis (Option A): Vestibular neuritis typically presents as sudden-onset, persistent vertigo accompanied by nausea, vomiting, imbalance, and a sensation of visual motion (oscillopsia), often mimicking constant head rotation. It results from an acute peripheral vestibular lesion, most commonly affecting the vestibular nerve, and unlike BPPV, vertigo persists even when the head is still.

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (Option C): Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV) presents with brief, recurrent episodes of vertigo triggered by changes in head position relative to gravity, such as turning in bed or looking up. It is caused by dislodged calcium carbonate crystals (otoconia) entering the semicircular canals (most often the posterior canal) leading to vertigo and positional nystagmus.

Acoustic neuroma (Option D): Acoustic neuromas also known as vestibular schwannomas typically present with gradually worsening unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and reduced vestibular function. Vertigo is uncommon due to central compensation of the slowly progressing vestibular deficit.

questions.text: A young lady visits her neurologist complaining of episodes of generalised weakness after arguments with her partner. She also complains of seeing goblins upon waking up. At work as a secretary, she has difficulty staying awake and has also had sleep attacks. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features of excessive daytime sleepiness, hypnopompic hallucinations, and

  • Narcolepsy is a chronic sleep disorder marked by excessive daytime sleepiness, abnormal REM sleep regulation, and disturbed nighttime sleep.
  • Affected individuals often experience irresistible sleep episodes during the day and may fall asleep at inappropriate times, yet awaken refreshed.
  • Classic REM-related symptoms include cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone triggered by emotions), hypnagogic (at sleep onset) or hypnopompic (on awakening) hallucinations, and sleep paralysis.
  • Cataplexy may cause collapse without loss of consciousness and is diagnostic when triggered by laughter or surprise.
  • Narcolepsy typically starts between ages 10 and 20 and persists lifelong. The condition is primarily due to the destruction of hypothalamic neurons that produce orexin (hypocretin), a neuropeptide crucial for sustaining wakefulness and regulating REM sleep.
  • Type 1 narcolepsy (with cataplexy) is associated with extremely low orexin levels in cerebrospinal fluid and nearly complete loss of orexin-producing neurons. Type 2 narcolepsy (without cataplexy) generally has normal orexin levels and may have alternate mechanisms.
  • The disorder is often linked to HLA-DQB1*06:02 and may follow autoimmune insults, including after infections or vaccines like H1N1 influenza.
  • Diagnosis relies on polysomnography followed by multiple sleep latency testing (MSLT), which confirms abnormal REM onset and daytime sleepiness, with most patients falling asleep within 8 minutes and entering REM in at least two of five naps. Cataplexy is seen in about half of narcoleptic individuals and is diagnostically useful.
  • Treatment is symptomatic, aiming to improve alertness and manage sleep episodes. Lifestyle adjustments, including consistent night sleep and scheduled daytime naps, are first-line.
  • Pharmacologic options include modafinil, methylphenidate, and dextroamphetamine for daytime alertness, and sodium oxybate or solriamfetol for both sleepiness and cataplexy. Pitolisant, an H3 antagonist, is another effective option with minimal side effects.

Explanation of other options:

Atonic seizures (Option B): Atonic seizures involve a sudden, brief loss of muscle tone, typically lasting 1 - 2 seconds, which may cause a quick head drop or a complete fall (known as a drop attack). Although consciousness is mildly affected, there is usually no confusion afterward.

Typical absence seizures (Option C): Typical absence seizures involve sudden, brief lapses in awareness lasting only a few seconds, without loss of muscle tone or postictal confusion. They are often present in children aged 4 -10 and may be accompanied by subtle, repetitive movements like blinking or chewing, sometimes occurring multiple times daily without the child realizing.

Obstructive sleep apnoea (Option D): Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA) is marked by repeated episodes of breathing interruption during sleep such as snoring, gasping, or choking and can lead to significant daytime fatigue or sleepiness despite adequate sleep duration. It is diagnosed using the apnea-hypopnea index (AHI), with five or more events per hour indicating OSA, or 15 or more even in the absence of symptoms.

questions.text: A 44-year-old retropositive patient has been having fevers, neck stiffness and confusion. A CT scan was done which was reported to be normal. CSF examination revealed elevated lymphocytes (88), and protein (5.5 g/l), and a low glucose. CSF adenosine deaminase was negative. Gram staining and India ink preparation revealed 4-7 micron, round budding yeasts with capsule and 8-10 lymphocytes per high power field. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features of meningitis in an immunocompromised patient, elevated lymphocytes and proteins in CSF, along with the microscopic findings suggests a diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis.

  • Cryptococcal meningitis, predominantly caused by Cryptococcus neoformans and Cryptococcus gattii, is the most common fungal meningitis in AIDS patients and serves as an AIDS-defining illness especially in those with CD4+ T-cell counts below 100/µL.
  • It presents as a subacute meningoencephalitis characterized by fever, headache, altered mental status, nausea, vomiting, and meningeal signs. Seizures and focal neurological deficits are less frequent.
  • CSF findings may be mild, with slightly raised WBCs or protein, low glucose, and increased opening pressure.
  • About one-third of cases also show pulmonary involvement, and cutaneous or disseminated disease may manifest with lesions mimicking molluscum contagiosum.
  • The diagnosis is confirmed via India ink staining or cryptococcal antigen testing of CSF, with blood cultures often yielding the organism.
  • Initial therapy involves amphotericin B with flucytosine for at least 2 weeks, followed by fluconazole until immune recovery (CD4+ >200 cells/µL).
  • Lumbar punctures may be repeated to manage raised intracranial pressure. ART initiation can trigger IRIS (Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome), leading to symptom worsening, thus timing must be managed carefully.
  • Epidemiologically, C. neoformans is associated with bird droppings and affects immunocompromised hosts globally, while C. gattii is found in certain trees and more often affects immunocompetent individuals in specific regions.
  • Cryptococcus can cross the blood-brain barrier via direct migration or through infected macrophages acting as "Trojan horses." Its capsule and melanin contribute to immune evasion and virulence.

The various CSF findings in different pathologies are given below.

Explanations of other options:

Mumps meningitis (Option A): Mumps meningitis often occurs in late winter or early spring and is more frequent in males. It may present with associated features such as parotitis, orchitis, or elevated serum amylase/lipase, although these are not always present. CSF findings typically show pleocytosis (often >1000 cells/µL) with lymphocytic predominance, and hypoglycorrhachia may occur in up to 30% of cases.

Tuberculous meningitis (Option B): Tuberculous meningitis arises from hematogenous spread of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Clinically, it presents subacutely with persistent headache, fever, fatigue, night sweats, and neck stiffness. CSF analysis typically reveals elevated opening pressure, lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and low glucose concentrations with elevated adenosine deaminase levels.

Carcinomatous meningitis (Option D): Carcinomatous meningitis results from the spread of malignant cells to the cerebrospinal fluid and can present even without obvious signs of the primary tumor. It is a recognized cause of chronic meningitis, and clinical clues such as a breast lump, abnormal pigmented skin lesion, localized bone pain, firm lymphadenopathy, or an abdominal mass may raise suspicion. This option can be ruled out since there are no features suggesting an underlying neoplasm.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man has left sided sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus since the past eight months. He has noticed his hearing loss to be progressing. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on clinical features of unilateral progressive sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus is a vestibular schwannoma which is a cerebellopontine angle tumour.

  • Vestibular schwannomas, also known as acoustic neuromas, are benign tumors originating from Schwann cells, commonly involving the vestibular part of the eighth cranial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle.
  • They usually present with slowly progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, vestibular hypofunction, and sometimes tinnitus or dizziness. However, vertigo is often absent due to central compensation.
  • Neurofibromatosis type 2 is associated with bilateral tumors, while NF1 increases the risk of spinal nerve schwannomas.
  • MRI reveals contrast-enhancing lesions often expanding the internal auditory canal.
  • Meningioma is a differential diagnosis.
  • Management depends on tumor size, symptoms, and patient preference. Small asymptomatic tumors may be monitored, while larger ones typically require surgery or stereotactic radiosurgery. Early surgical intervention is preferred for hearing preservation when feasible.

Explanations of other options:

Frontal lobe tumour (Option A): Frontal lobe tumors usually present with anosmia, personality changes, and seizures.

Cavernous sinus thrombosis (Option B): Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a severe condition that typically presents with facial or orbital pain, eye swelling, chemosis, fever, and cranial nerve palsies involving the third, fourth, sixth, and ophthalmic (V1) and sometimes maxillary (V2) branches of the trigeminal nerve. It most commonly arises from infections like orbital cellulitis or sinusitis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, and may spread bilaterally due to the interconnection between the cavernous sinuses.


Ramsay Hunt syndrome (Option C): Ramsay Hunt syndrome is caused by varicella zoster virus and presents with ear pain and vesicular eruptions in the external auditory canal, along with loss of taste sensation on the front two-thirds of the tongue.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of two episodes of seizures witnessed by his family member. On examination, he appears well, with no focal neurological deficit. A CT scan shows multiple calcified cystic lesions in the brain. He gives a history of travelling to South America 5 years ago. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Neurocysticercosis, the most prevalent parasitic CNS infection worldwide, results from ingestion of Taenia solium eggs, leading to cysticerci lodging in the brain.
  • Clinically, it presents with new-onset partial seizures, sometimes progressing to generalized seizures, or focal neurological deficits.
  • When cysts obstruct CSF flow in subarachnoid or ventricular spaces, they may cause increased intracranial pressure, and spinal lesions can mimic tumors.
  • Symptoms arise mainly during cyst degeneration, which provokes an inflammatory response, typically resulting in seizures. D
  • Diagnosis relies on neuroimaging; MRI or CT can show four stages: vesicular (live larva), colloidal (edema with contrast enhancement), granulonodular (ring-enhancing lesion), and calcified (inactive).
  • Management involves antiepileptic drugs for seizure control and cysticidal therapy (albendazole ± praziquantel) depending on lesion stage and viability.
  • Anti-inflammatory agents like corticosteroids are given before antiparasitic drugs to reduce inflammation.
  • Long-term antiepileptic treatment is continued if seizures persist or until imaging confirms lesion resolution and seizure freedom for 2 years. Calcified lesions do not require cysticidal treatment.

The following image shows calcified cysts in neurocysticercosis.

Explanations of other options:

Neurosarcoidosis (Option A): Neurosarcoidosis can affect any part of the nervous system and commonly presents with cranial nerve palsies, especially facial nerve involvement resembling Bell';s palsy, basilar meningitis, myelopathy, and hypothalamic dysfunction leading to diabetes insipidus. Optic neuritis is another frequent manifestation and may be associated with uveitis.

Multiple sclerosis (Option C): Multiple sclerosis presents with a wide range of symptoms depending on lesion location, including sensory disturbances like paresthesias, visual changes due to optic neuritis or diplopia, limb weakness, facial weakness, and spasticity. Additional features include pain, ataxia, vertigo, and in some cases bladder or cognitive dysfunction. Symptoms can be intermittent or progressive, and MRI often reveals demyelinated plaques as Dawson's fingers.

Subdural empyema (Option D): Patients with subdural empyema typically present with fever and a progressively worsening headache, especially in the setting of sinusitis. As the condition progresses, symptoms may include focal neurological deficits, most commonly contralateral hemiparesis or hemiplegia, along with seizures (which may start focally and generalize), nuchal rigidity, and signs of raised intracranial pressure. Gadolinium enhanced MRI helps to delineate the rim of the empyema.

questions.text: A 41 year old woman with a BMI of 28 kg/m2 presents with a history of headaches. She also reports menstrual irregularities. Fundoscopy revealed bilateral papilledema. Tone, power and reflexes in the limbs were normal. Investigations show a normal CT scan and MRI Lumbar puncture reveals elevated CSF pressure but the constituents of CSF are normal. Which of the following would suggest that a complication has arisen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of raised intracranial tension in an obese female with normal CT, MRI, and lumbar puncture points to a diagnosis of idiopathic intracranial hypertension causing papilledema and fulminant papilledema can cause rapid onset visual loss.

  • Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), also known as pseudotumor cerebri, is a condition marked by increased intracranial pressure without an identifiable cause and is commonly associated with obesity, female sex, and sometimes pregnancy.
  • Patients usually present with a morning-predominant generalized headache that worsens with lying down and may be accompanied by transient visual disturbances, especially during severe headaches.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by detecting papilledema or elevated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure via lumbar puncture after ruling out structural causes with MRI and MR venography.
  • First-line treatment includes acetazolamide, with topiramate as an alternative. Severe or unresponsive cases may need surgical interventions like CSF shunting, along with weight reduction.

Explanations of other options:

Bitemporal hemianopia (Option A): Usually seen in lesions of optic chiasma.

4th nerve palsy (Option C): The cranial nerve commonly involved in raised intracranial pressure is abducens (6th cranial) nerve.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man has been on high dose prednisolone for giant cell arteritis since the past 4 months. He now complains of a headache which has worsened for the past week and is associated with double vision. On examination, there is neck stiffness, and right sided 7th nerve palsy. His temperature is 38 degrees. A lumbar puncture reveals elevated mildly WBC count (predominantly neutrophils) and protein and low glucose. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features, CSF findings and history of long-term steroid use is bacterial meningitis caused by Listeria monocytogenes.

  • Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive, facultatively anaerobic bacillus that causes infection mainly through contaminated food, especially in high-risk groups such as pregnant women, neonates, older adults, and the immunocompromised.
  • It can survive and grow at low temperatures, tolerate acidic and salty environments, and demonstrates tumbling motility on microscopy.
  • Infection typically results in gastroenteritis in healthy individuals but can lead to invasive diseases like bacteremia and CNS involvement in vulnerable populations.
  • CNS manifestations include meningoencephalitis, often with altered mental status, seizures, and cranial nerve abnormalities.
  • Neuroinvasive listeriosis may present with cerebellar and brainstem signs such as ataxia, cranial neuropathies, and hemiparesis. It is classically seen as a biphasic illness (fever and headache followed by neurologic deterioration).
  • Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis commonly shows normal WBC count and neutrophilic predominance is less marked than other bacterial causes and lymphocytic predominance can also be seen. Glucose levels are usually low.
  • Diagnosis is made by isolating the organism from sterile sites such as blood or CSF.
  • First-line treatment includes high-dose IV ampicillin or penicillin, often combined with gentamicin for synergy. TMP-SMX is an alternative in penicillin-allergic patients but should be avoided in early pregnancy.

Explanation of other options:

Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Option A): Tuberculous meningitis results from the bloodstream dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It generally presents with a gradual onset of symptoms such as ongoing headache, fever, neck rigidity, fatigue, and night sweats. Cerebrospinal fluid findings usually show increased opening pressure, a predominance of lymphocytes, elevated protein, reduced glucose levels, and raised adenosine deaminase activity.

Mycoplasma pneumoniae (Option B): Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection commonly presents as a gradual-onset upper respiratory illness with pharyngitis, bronchitis, or pneumonia, characterized by nonproductive cough, fever, headache, and malaise. Extrapulmonary manifestations may involve neurologic complications such as meningoencephalitis which can mimic a viral etiology.

Borrelia burgdorferi (Option D): Lyme disease progresses through distinct stages: the early localized stage presents with erythema migrans, often a red expanding skin lesion at the site of a tick bite. In the disseminated stage, patients may develop systemic symptoms such as fever, headache, myalgias, lymphadenopathy, and various neurologic or cardiac abnormalities like facial palsy, radiculoneuropathy, or heart block. Late-stage infection may lead to intermittent or persistent oligoarticular arthritis (especially in the knees), chronic neurologic complications, or dermatologic manifestations like acrodermatitis chronica atrophicans.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy with a mild learning disability presents for an assessment. He was apparently well 5 years ago, when he developed jaundice which persisted for 4 months. He was found to have difficulty speaking, walking up the stairs and he also had choreoathetoid movements of the arms. On examination there was jaundice and had Kayser Fleisher rings confirmed by slit-lamp examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features of jaundice, difficulty in speaking, choreoathetoid movements, and Kayser Fleisher rings is Wilson's disease.

  • Wilson's disease is a hereditary disorder of copper metabolism that mainly affects the liver and brain due to mutations in the ATP7B gene.
  • Deficiency of this ATPase results in copper accumulation in tissues. Early detection and lifelong treatment are essential to prevent premature mortality.
  • Liver disease typically presents before age 30 and may manifest as jaundice, hepatomegaly, ascites, or viral-like hepatitis.
  • Neurological signs include dysarthria, dystonia, tremors, and psychiatric changes like irritability, mood disorders, or schizophrenia.
  • Eye involvement may be detected as Kayser-Fleischer rings in Descemet's membrane and, less commonly, sunflower cataracts. Secondary effects involve renal tubular dysfunction, bone/joint disease, and anemia.
  • Diagnostic lab findings include low serum ceruloplasmin and copper, increased urinary copper excretion (>100 μg/day), elevated liver enzymes, and increased hepatic copper content (>200 μg/g dry weight).
  • First-line agents in management include D-penicillamine and trientine, both binding copper to enhance excretion. Zinc acetate and tetrathiomolybdate are other drugs used.
  • Liver Transplantation is reserved for advanced or treatment-resistant cases with irreversible hepatic damage.

Explanations of other options:

CJD (Option A): Patients typically present with a swiftly worsening decline in cognitive function, accompanied by psychiatric manifestations like depression, anxiety, or psychosis. Neurologically, they may develop myoclonus, visual impairments, cerebellar ataxia, and signs indicating involvement of both pyramidal and extrapyramidal systems.

Alzheimer's disease (Option B): Alzheimer's disease typically begins with memory loss and gradually progresses to impair other cognitive functions like language, visuospatial skills, and executive function. As the disease advances, patients may experience difficulty with daily tasks, language deficits, apraxia, disorientation, behavioral changes, and eventually lose the ability to walk, speak, or care for themselves.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis(Option C): ALS is characterized by the presence of both upper and lower motor neuron signs, including progressive muscle weakness, wasting, fasciculations, spasticity, and increased reflexes, usually affecting both sides of the body symmetrically. Involvement of the bulbar region may lead to speech difficulties (dysarthria) and pseudobulbar affect, while sensory perception, bowel and bladder control, and eye movements are generally preserved, even in the later stages of the disease.

questions.text: A 61-year-old chronic alcoholic patient presents with disorientation and confusion. A friend says he has been confabulating about having his wallet stolen and has been having gaps in memory. On examination, he is unkempt, his pupil reflexes are normal and eye movements are normal. There were otherwise no focal neurological deficits. A CT scan of the brain showed mild cerebral atrophy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of confabulation and memory deficits in a chronic alcoholic patient suggests a diagnosis of Korsakoff psychosis.

  • Korsakoff's psychosis is a persistent amnestic syndrome that often follows Wernicke's encephalopathy and is marked by severe impairment in forming new memories, despite preserved immediate memory, attention, and alertness.
  • Patients typically appear alert and cooperative but quickly forget new information, becoming confused and disoriented.
  • They may fill in memory gaps with fabricated stories (confabulation), and commonly exhibit memory gaps, disordered temporal sequencing, and poor recall of recent events while older memories remain relatively preserved.
  • The condition results from irreversible damage, particularly to the medial thalamic nuclei and mammillary bodies, due to prolonged thiamine deficiency. There is no specific treatment once structural damage has occurred.

Explanation of other options:

Transient global amnesia (Option A): Transient global amnesia is typically seen in late middle age and presents with sudden disorientation and repeated questioning about identity and surroundings. It involves both anterograde amnesia for new information and retrograde amnesia for recent events before the onset, usually resolving within 24 - 48 hours. Possible causes include migraine, temporal lobe seizures, and posterior cerebral perfusion abnormalities.

Wernicke's encephalopathy (Option C): Wernicke's disease, caused by thiamine deficiency, commonly presents with the triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and global confusion, though most patients show only partial features such as disorientation, apathy, and inattentiveness. Ocular signs include horizontal nystagmus, lateral rectus palsy, and gaze abnormalities, while gait instability arises from combined cerebellar and vestibular dysfunction.

Alzheimer's disease (Option D): Alzheimer's disease usually starts with memory impairment and gradually affects additional cognitive abilities such as language, spatial awareness, and executive functioning. As it progresses, individuals may struggle with routine activities, develop speech and motor planning difficulties, become disoriented, show behavioral alterations, and ultimately lose the capacity to communicate, ambulate, or manage self-care.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with sudden, severe, electric shock-like pain in her right cheek and jaw that lasts for a few seconds and recurs multiple times a day, often triggered by activities like chewing, talking, or brushing her teeth. She reports that touching certain areas on her face provokes the pain, but neurological examination shows no sensory deficits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical vignette of sudden, shock-like pain over the cheek that lasts for a few seconds which gets triggered on touching is suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia.

  • Trigeminal neuralgia, also known as tic douloureux, is marked by sudden, intense bouts of facial pain typically affecting the lips, gums, cheeks, or chin, and rarely involving the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve.
  • These painful episodes may last only seconds to minutes but recur frequently, often triggered by routine actions like talking, chewing, or touching certain facial areas.
  • These trigger zones are often located on the face or tongue and respond to minor stimuli such as wind, washing the face, or brushing teeth. Despite severe pain, objective sensory loss is not detectable on examination.
  • The condition is more prevalent in middle-aged and older adults, particularly women. It typically begins abruptly and may continue for weeks or months before periods of remission, although symptoms often return over time.
  • Pathophysiologically, the condition is thought to stem from abnormal electrical activity in pain fibers near the trigeminal nerve root, often due to compression by vessels like the superior cerebellar artery.
  • Diagnosis relies on clinical features, and in some cases, especially bilateral involvement or young onset, MRI may be needed to rule out underlying causes such as multiple sclerosis or mass lesions. Temporal arteritis and other headache syndromes must also be excluded.
  • Treatment starts with carbamazepine, effective in most patients. Alternatives include oxcarbazepine, phenytoin, and lamotrigine. If medications fail, surgical options like microvascular decompression, gamma knife radiosurgery, or radiofrequency rhizotomy can be considered.

Explanations of other options:

Paroxysmal hemicrania (Option A): Paroxysmal hemicrania presents as frequent, short-lived, and severe unilateral headaches, often retroorbital but sometimes spreading across the head. These attacks are typically accompanied by autonomic signs like tearing and nasal congestion, and they occur more than five times a day, each lasting between 2 to 45 minutes.

Glossopharyngeal neuralgia (Option C): Glossopharyngeal neuralgia is marked by sudden, severe, stabbing pain originating on one side of the throat near the tonsillar region, often radiating to the ear or jaw. Attacks may be triggered by swallowing or coughing and resemble trigeminal neuralgia but are much rarer. There are typically no motor or sensory deficits, although some cases may include cardiac manifestations such as bradycardia, hypotension, or fainting.

Bell's palsy (Option D): Bell's palsy typically begins suddenly, reaching peak facial weakness within 48 hours. Patients may have preceding pain near the ear, and some experience loss of taste on one side or sensitivity to sound (hyperacusis).

questions.text: A 61-year-old man has had 6 seizures over the past week. The seizures are generalised tonic clonic. He has complained of a severe headache, and examination shows increased tone on the left with mild hemiparesis. There is papilledema in both eyes. An emergency MRI scan shows a mass in the right cerebral hemisphere. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical vignette of seizures, headache, and imaging showing mass in the right cerebral hemisphere is glioblastoma.

  • Glioblastoma, the most prevalent malignant primary brain tumor, typically arises in the sixth or seventh decade and presents with symptoms such as headache, seizures, or focal neurological deficits.
  • Histologically classified as grade IV astrocytoma, glioblastomas may or may not carry IDH mutations, which influence prognosis and classification.
  • Tumors with IDH mutations (secondary glioblastomas) tend to have better outcomes, while IDH-wildtype glioblastomas exhibit aggressive features including necrosis and endothelial proliferation, with associated molecular changes like EGFR amplification and TERT promoter mutations.
  • These tumors often appear as ring-enhancing lesions with necrotic centers and surrounding edema and show infiltrative growth patterns extending beyond the visible margins.
  • Standard treatment involves maximal surgical resection followed by radiotherapy with concurrent and adjuvant temozolomide.
  • Poor prognostic indicators include older age, absence of IDH mutations, poor functional status, and tumors that cannot be fully resected.
  • Gliosarcomas, a variant of glioblastoma with both astrocytic and sarcomatous components, are managed similarly.

The following image shows the CT image of glioblastoma.

Explanations of other options:

Medulloblastoma (Option A): Medulloblastomas are the most frequent malignant brain tumors in children and commonly originate from granular or multipotent progenitor cells. They typically appear on MRI as enhancing posterior fossa masses and present with symptoms like headache, ataxia, and brainstem signs.
Craniopharyngioma (Option B): Craniopharyngiomas are uncommon, typically suprasellar benign tumors with solid or mixed solid-cystic components, often showing calcification, and originate from remnants of Rathke's pouch. They exhibit a bimodal age distribution, affecting mainly children and adults aged 55 -65, and can cause symptoms such as headaches, visual disturbances, growth issues in children, and hypopituitarism in adults.

Meningioma (Option C): Meningiomas, the most common primary brain tumors, originate from meningothelial cells of the dura and are often found incidentally on imaging, especially in older women and those with NF2 or prior cranial irradiation. They typically appear as densely enhancing extra-axial masses with a dural tail and may present with seizures, headaches, or neurological deficits.

questions.text: A 28-year-old previously healthy woman has a sudden onset of mental confusion.She has a seizure and is brought to the hospital. A lumbar puncture reveals a normal opening pressure, and clear, colourless cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is obtained with a few RBCs, lymphocytic pleocytosis and normal glucose and protein levels. An MRI scan reveals swelling of the right temporal lobe with haemorrhagic areas.mWhich of the following infectious agents is the most likely cause for these findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of seizures, confusion, RBCs in CSF with lymphocytic pleocytosis and MRI revealing hemorrhagic areas in temporal lobe suggests a diagnosis of encephalitis due to herpes simplex virus.

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV), primarily HSV-1, accounts for the majority of sporadic viral encephalitis cases with a biphasic age distribution peaking at 5 -30 and over 50 years.
  • In HSV encephalitis, patients present with acute onset of fever and focal neurologic signs, especially affecting the temporal lobes, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows elevated protein, lymphocytic pleocytosis, and red cells due to necrosis.
  • Diagnosis relies on PCR detection of HSV DNA in CSF and treatment with IV acyclovir significantly reduces mortality, though neurologic sequelae are common, especially in older adults.
  • HSV meningitis is generally self-limited and presents with fever, headache, and mild photophobia lasting 2-7 days. HSV is a leading cause of recurrent lymphocytic meningitis (Mollaret's).

Explanation of other options:

Haemophilus influenzae (Option A): Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) can cause bacterial meningitis, particularly in children under two years old, presenting with fever and impaired central nervous system function, though neck stiffness may not always be present. CSF findings are those typically seen in bacterial meningitis.

Influenza virus (Option C): Influenza virus can cause viral encephalitis and CSF findings include lymphocytic pleocytosis, normal protein and glucose but RBCs and hemorrhagic areas in the temporal lobe are characteristic of HSV encephalitis.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Option D): Tuberculous meningitis results from the bloodstream dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and usually presents gradually with ongoing headache, fever, fatigue, night sweats, and neck rigidity. Cerebrospinal fluid findings commonly include increased opening pressure, a predominance of lymphocytes, reduced glucose levels, and elevated adenosine deaminase activity.

questions.text: A 41-year-old HIV-seropositive man presents to the emergency department with a two week history of global headache. His partner says that he has become increasingly confused and disorientated. The patient's latest CD4 count, taken three weeks ago, was 50 cells/mm3. On examination, he had mild weakness of his left arm and leg in all muscle groups and a right homonymous hemianopia. MRI shows asymmetric white matter lesions with no mass or enhancement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • PML is a demyelinating disease caused by JC virus (JCV), marked by widespread multifocal demyelinating lesions in the brain sparing the spinal cord and optic nerves.
  • It typically affects immunocompromised individuals, with most cases associated with AIDS, hematologic cancers, or immunomodulatory therapy like natalizumab.
  • Patients may present with visual disturbances typically homonymous hemianopia, cognitive decline, motor weakness, ataxia, and seizures, and MRI shows asymmetric white matter lesions in periventricular regions without enhancement, though enhancement may occur in drug-related PML.
  • Diagnosis relies on detecting JCV DNA in CSF by PCR, which has high specificity but variable sensitivity. A negative result doesn't exclude the diagnosis.
  • Brain biopsy may be needed in ambiguous cases, and serologic testing for JCV antibodies helps assess risk in those on natalizumab.

Explanations of other options:

CNS lymphoma (Option A): Primary CNS lymphomas are common in retropositive individuals and can be seen as a mass lesion on imaging which can be multifocal or ring-enhancing in some cases.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis (Option B): Presenting features include seizures,focal neurological deficits, meningitis, and meningoencephalitis. Imaging reveals ring enhancing lesions.

Neurosyphilis (Option C): Neurosyphilis is characterised by early meningeal and meningovascular involvement. Tabes dorsalis and general paresis is seen in late stages.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old girl presented with fever, headache and photophobia.
Investigations revealed:
Cerebrospinal fluid examination
Opening pressure 260 mm H20 (50-180)
Total protein 0.8 g/l (0.15-0.45)
Glucose 4.2 mmol/l (3.3-4.4)
White cell count 60 per ml (<5)
Lymphocytes 90% (60-70)
Plasma glucose 6.4 mmol/l (3.0-6.0)
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Normal cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) glucose together with a CSF lymphocytosis, an increased opening pressure, and a markedly raised CSF protein are typical of a viral meningitis.

Explanations of other options:

Bacterial meningitis (Option A): CSF findings in bacterial meningitis include elevated WBC count with neutrophilic predominance, reduced glucose, and increased protein.

Tuberculosis meningitis (Option B): Tuberculous meningitis is marked by lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, normal to low glucose, and increased adenosine deaminase levels in CSF.

Fungal meningitis (Option C): CSF findings include lymphocytic or neutrophilic pleocytosis (depending on the organism), increased protein, and normal to reduced glucose.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman presents to the clinic having had five blackouts over the last year, all while she is standing up. She gets warnings of blurred vision, nausea, and feeling hot. The attacks last 30 to 60 seconds. She recovers quickly after the attacks. She has never bitten her tongue or sustained any injuries. Physical examination and an ECG are normal. Her grandmother and sister suffer from epilepsy. Which of the following investigations is the most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features point to a diagnosis of vasovagal syncope for which the most appropriate investigation is tilt table test.

  • Vasovagal syncope, also known as common faint, is a type of neurally mediated syncope triggered by factors such as emotional distress, pain, or orthostatic stress.
  • During an episode, there is a drop in blood pressure and heart rate, potentially leading to brief asystole, EEG flattening, and transient loss of consciousness.
  • Diagnosis can be confirmed using tilt table testing, which reproduces symptoms with high sensitivity and specificity by simulating the provocative conditions, often revealing a characteristic "slow-flat-slow" EEG pattern during syncope.

Explanations of other options:

24 hour ECG recording (Option A): Since the patient exhibits no signs of coronary heart disease, this is not an appropriate investigation.

CT brain (Option B): The patient has no signs of mass lesions in the brain or CNS infections.

Psychiatric evaluation (Option D): If the tilt table test produces symptoms without hemodynamic changes, a psychiatric evaluation to rule out psychogenic syncope.

choices.text: Rapid rehydration with 5% dextrose is indicated
She should be treated with sodium restriction
She has the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)

questions.text:
A 19-year-old woman sustains severe head injuries in a road traffic accident.
The following day her investigations show:
Sodium 160 mmol/l (137-144)
Potassium 3.7 mmol/l (3.5-4.9)
Chloride 120 mmol/l (95-107)
Urea and Creatinine are Normal
Which one of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features of hypernatremia, increased chloride levels in a patient suffering from head injuries is diabetes insipidus in which the urine osmolality will be low.

  • Diabetes insipidus (DI) is defined by excessive excretion of dilute urine (>40 mL/kg/day) and low urine osmolality (<280 mOsm/L), often accompanied by increased thirst and frequent urination.
  • It is categorized into four types as given in the table below.
  • Diagnosis involves evaluating urine output, plasma osmolality, and AVP levels, often with fluid deprivation and response to desmopressin.
  • MRI may reveal posterior pituitary signal loss in central DI.
  • Central DI is often genetic, with mutations affecting AVP production or transport, and may evolve from partial to complete over time.
  • Primary polydipsia includes dipsogenic, psychogenic, and iatrogenic forms, while nephrogenic DI can result from drugs like lithium or inherited Vreceptor mutations.
  • Treatment of central DI is with desmopressin which concentrates urine and controls thirst, while nephrogenic DI is managed with dietary measures, thiazide diuretics, and NSAIDs
  • Primary polydipsia is not responsive to desmopressin and requires behavioral interventions to prevent water intoxication.

Explanation of other options:

Rapid rehydration with 5% dextrose is indicated (Option A): Has no role in the treatment of diabetes insipidus.

She should be treated with sodium restriction (Option B): Sodium restriction is used in the management of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

She has the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) (Option C): SIADH is characterised by hyponatremia and reduced urine output.

choices.text: She is likely to have been prescribed an antipsychotic
She should be treated with parenteral procyclidine
She should receive procyclidine as long term prophylaxis

questions.text: An 18-year-old female is admitted with an oculogyric crisis. Which of the following statements about this condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Prophylaxis is not used for oculogyric crisis which is a form of acute dystonia, as the risks far outweigh the benefits.

  • Acute dystonia refers to sudden or prolonged involuntary muscle contractions that lead to abnormal movements or postures.
  • These may include oculogyric crises, tongue protrusion, jaw clenching (trismus), neck twisting (torticollis), and dystonic spasms of the limbs and trunk.
  • Laryngeal and glossopharyngeal involvement may result in speech and swallowing difficulties or even breathing issues, potentially leading to cyanosis.
  • Children are more prone to exhibit severe posturing such as opisthotonos, along with scoliosis and writhing. These episodes are distressing and can deter patients from continuing their medications.
  • Symptoms usually emerge early during antipsychotic therapy, particularly with high-potency agents or in younger males. (Option A ruled out)
  • The condition is most frequently triggered by intramuscular administration of potent antipsychotics, attributed to dopaminergic overactivity in the basal ganglia when CNS drug levels drop between doses
  • Seizures and tardive dyskinesia must be ruled out during diagnosis. (Option B ruled out) Dystonia often fluctuates or improves with reassurance, which may mislead clinicians into misinterpreting the movements as psychogenic.
  • Acute episodes typically respond well to intramuscular or intravenous anticholinergics such as procyclidine. (Option C ruled out) Other effective options include diazepam, amobarbital, caffeine sodium benzoate, and hypnosis.
  • If the adverse effect recurs or becomes intolerable, switching the antipsychotic may be advisable.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presented to hospital with recurrent fever, rigors, and worsening fatigue. He had returned from a business trip to West Africa six months previously. There has been no contact with animals. Examination reveals no splenomegaly or skin discolouration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of recurrent fevers with chills with history of travel to West Africa points to a diagnosis of Plasmodium ovale malaria.

  • Malaria is a protozoan disease transmitted by female Anopheles mosquitoes, primarily affecting tropical regions. It is caused by Plasmodium species and remains a major global health concern.
  • The main species of Plasmodium which cause infection in humans are P.falciparum, P.malariae, P.vivax, P.ovale, and P.knowlesii.
  • ovale is commonly found in Africa, due to its ability to infect only non-Duffy blood group individuals as people there are duffy negative.
  • vivax and P.ovale have liver hypnozoites in their life cycle which causes relapses.Initial symptoms are nonspecific, including fever, malaise, headache, fatigue, and muscle aches. Classic malarial paroxysms (fever, chills, rigors) with irregular fever patterns are common.
  • Severe features may include seizures in children, anemia, jaundice, and splenomegaly, especially in areas of unstable transmission.
  • Definitive diagnosis is by identifying asexual Plasmodium forms in stained peripheral blood smears (thick and thin).
  • Giemsa stain is preferred, and rapid diagnostic tests like HRP2-based assays are also used. Additional lab findings may show anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, raised bilirubin, and elevated inflammatory markers in severe disease.

Explanation of other options:

  1. Visceral leishmaniasis: The most frequent clinical manifestation of visceral leishmaniasis (VL) is the sudden onset of moderate to high fever accompanied by chills and rigors. The fever may persist for several weeks, gradually lessening in severity, sometimes followed by a brief afebrile phase before recurring. Splenic enlargement typically becomes detectable by the second week and can become massive as the illness progresses. This is usually followed by moderate enlargement of the liver.
  2. Brucellosis: Brucellosis is a zoonosis transmitted directly or indirectly from infected animals. The incubation period of brucellosis is usually one to three weeks, but sometimes may be several months. If left untreated it results in a characteristic undulating fever. Other features include night sweats, fatigue, and musculoskeletal symptoms.
  3. Plasmodium falciparum malaria: The clinical history of recurrent episodes of fever rules out this option since P.falciparum does not have liver hypnozoites in its lifecycle.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman has presented to the emergency department for the third time with abdominal pain which typically lasts several days. The previous two occasions she has been discharged home without a firm diagnosis. Between episodes the patient is symptom free. She also reports feeling anxious frequently and has had hallucinations. She has recently re-started the combined oral contraceptive pill after completing her family.On examination she is anxious and hypertensive at 155/98 mmHg with a pulse of 102. She has no rashes. Her abdomen is diffusely tender. Abdominal imaging reveals no significant findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features of non-specific abdominal pain, anxiety, and history of using oral contraceptive pills is acute intermittent porphyria.

  • Porphyrias are metabolic conditions stemming from either a deficiency or overactivity of specific enzymes within the heme biosynthetic pathway.
  • These disorders may be inherited in autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, or X-linked patterns, except for porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT), which often occurs sporadically.
  • Based on the primary site of porphyrin precursor accumulation, porphyrias are categorized as hepatic or erythropoietic, and further classified as acute or cutaneous based on clinical manifestations.
  • Hepatic porphyrias primarily affect the liver and typically present with neurologic symptoms such as neuropathic abdominal pain, peripheral motor neuropathy, and psychiatric disturbances.
  • These symptoms are frequently triggered by factors like fasting, drugs, or hormonal changes. While hepatic porphyrias mostly manifest in adults, rare homozygous variants can cause symptoms before puberty.
  • In contrast, erythropoietic porphyrias present early in life, often from birth or even prenatally, and cause severe photosensitivity due to porphyrin accumulation in skin, leading to cell damage and disfigurement.
  • Among hepatic porphyrias, acute intermittent porphyria (AIP), hereditary coproporphyria (HCP), and variegate porphyria (VP) usually present with neurologic crises in adulthood, whereas delta-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase deficiency porphyria (ADP) appears earlier in life.
  • Acute Intermittent Porphyria is an autosomal dominant hepatic porphyria caused by partial deficiency of HMB-synthase enzyme. Attacks may be precipitated when heme synthesis is increased. Symptoms are more common in women and may be worsened during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle due to progesterone levels.
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda, although hepatic, presents with blistering skin lesions. Hereditary coproporphyria and variegate porphyria may also show skin involvement. (Option D ruled out).
  • Erythropoietic porphyrias include congenital erythropoietic porphyria (CEP), erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP), and X-linked protoporphyria (XLP). These are marked by excess porphyrins in bone marrow and erythrocytes, leading to photosensitivity.
  • CEP causes severe blistering lesions; EPP and XLP cause non-blistering, painful photosensitivity. EPP may affect liver function in a subset of patients, with a small percentage developing progressive liver disease. XLP closely resembles EPP in presentation.

Explanation of other options:

Appendicitis (Option B): Appendicitis presents with abdominal pain but it does not explain the psychiatric symptoms and absence of findings on abdominal imaging.

Depression (Option C): Does not explain the recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and hallucinations. The patient also experiences symptom-free intervals.
